body.p: These notes are loosely based on the system described by Michelle P. Brown in her Guide to Western Historical Scripts from Antiquity to 1600 (Toronto, 1993), but modified for the purposes of presentation of a painted inscription on the web. This is especially evident in the case of damage. Since the text is paint on wooden panels, rather than ink on a parchment or paper support, it makes it more likely that parts of letters can be lost through flaking, but the letter itself is still legible. Indicating damage is this way differs from the standard practice in Brown. For this reason, the editor has provided the following guide to his practice:

list.item: Expanded abbreviations in the text are indicated thusly: example.
Damaged material is indicated thusly: example.
A gap in the text through damage is indicated thusly:, where the number of dots indicate the likely number of missing letters based on the other witnesses.

Specific issues regarding the text will be indicated via a footnote either immediately after the item referenced or at the end of the line. They have been color-coded to indicate the type of note they are:
Explanatory notes provide the reasoning for the editorial choices made, with reference to the image provided. They are indicated thusly:.
Informational notes provide non-editorial contextual information such as particular scribal renderings or relationships between the witnesses. They are indicated thusly:.
Notes unrelated either to the specifics of the text or containing both explanatory and informational elements it is indicated thusly:.
